general_information.public_conversation_phase_2:
Round 1 / Speaker: Agent_2 Statement: Hey everyone, I'm Agent_2, and it's great to kick off our group discussion on this. After going through Part 1 and those application rounds, I've become really convinced that Maximizing Floor Income is the way to go for a just distribution. It directly focuses on lifting up the worst-off group—the Low class—which feels right to me because lifetime income is so influenced by things we can't control, like genetics or where we're born. In my rounds, choosing the floor principle protected me from really low payoffs when I got unlucky assignments, like landing in Low class for $13,000 (which was still better than the alternatives that could've dropped me to $6,000). Sure, it might not maximize the overall average, but with the random class assignments and higher stakes here, I don't want anyone getting stuck at the bottom if luck doesn't go their way.

What about you all? What did your Part 1 experiences show you—did you lean toward prioritizing the average, or something with constraints like a floor or range limit? I'd love to hear your rankings and thoughts so we can find some common ground.
Round 1 / Speaker: Agent_1 Statement: Hey everyone – thanks, Agent 2, for laying out the case so clearly. I’m Agent 1, and I’m in the same boat: after the four rounds in Part I I also ended up ranking Maximizing Floor Income as my top principle, followed by the floor‑constrained average, then the range‑constrained average, and finally pure average‑maximization.  

A couple of reasons why the floor‑maximizing rule feels like the most “just” choice to me:

1. Luck matters. As the experiment reminds us, our lifetime income is heavily shaped by genetic and social accidents that we can’t control. By guaranteeing the highest possible minimum income, we protect the people who are most vulnerable to those random shocks.

2. Risk‑aversion under high stakes. In the later rounds the payoff stakes are much larger, and the distribution we’ll face is unknown. A rule that maximizes the floor eliminates the worst‑case scenario of ending up with a very low payoff, which is especially important when the stakes are high.

3. Moral priority of the worst‑off. Even if we could squeeze a slightly higher average by ignoring the floor, that would come at the cost of leaving some participants with a dramatically lower outcome. The principle of lifting the lowest income aligns with the idea that a just society should first ensure that nobody falls below a decent threshold.

I do hear the concern that focusing solely on the floor might sacrifice some efficiency. If anyone feels that we should try to balance equity and efficiency, the next‑best option in my ranking is Maximizing Average with a Floor Constraint – it still guarantees a minimum while allowing a higher average. But I think, given the uncertainty of the upcoming distribution, the pure floor‑maximizing rule is the safest and most ethically sound bet.

Agent 3, I’d love to hear what you took away from your Part I rounds and where you stand on the ranking. If you’re on board with the floor‑maximizing principle (or at least have no strong objection), we could move toward a quick consensus and later, if needed, discuss any refinements.  

Looking forward to your thoughts!
Round 1 / Speaker: Agent_3 Statement: Hey everyone, thanks Agent_2 and Agent_1 for starting us off so thoughtfully—it's awesome to see we're already on the same page here. I'm Agent_3, and after diving deep into Part 1 with those explanation examples and the four real-stakes rounds, my ranking lines up exactly with yours: 1. Maximizing Floor Income, 2. Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint, 3. Maximizing Average with Range Constraint, and 4. Maximizing Average Income. I'm very sure about this, as the hands-on experience really drove it home for me.

In my rounds, I stuck with Floor Income every single time, even when it meant taking a lower personal payoff—like landing in the Medium low class for $14,000 ($1.40) in one round instead of potentially $20,000 under average maximization. But seeing how it consistently raised the lowest incomes to $13,000–$14,000 (versus dropping to $6,000–$12,000 in the alternatives) made it clear: with all the uncontrollable factors like genetics and luck shaping our incomes, protecting the worst-off feels like the core of justice. It minimizes those scary worst-case scenarios, especially with the higher stakes and unknown distribution in this phase. I totally agree with your points on risk-aversion and moral priority—nobody should get left behind just because of bad draws.

That said, if we want to balance in a bit more efficiency without fully sacrificing the floor, the constrained average could be a solid compromise, but I think pure Floor Income is the strongest starting point for true equity. Since we're all aligned on it as #1, are you guys up for voting on Maximizing Floor Income this round to lock it in? I'd love to hear if anyone has any tweaks or second thoughts first!
[Voting Confirmation] Agent_1: Confirmed
[Voting Confirmation] Agent_2: Confirmed
[Voting Confirmation] Agent_3: Confirmed (initiated vote)
All confirmed

detailed_explanation.response_to_demonstration:
Prompt: Here is how each justice principle would be applied to example income distributions:

Income Distributions:

| Income Class | Dist. 1 | Dist. 2 | Dist. 3 | Dist. 4 |
|--------------|---------|---------|---------|----------|
| High         | $32,000 | $28,000 | $31,000 | $21,000 |
| Medium high  | $27,000 | $22,000 | $24,000 | $20,000 |
| Medium       | $24,000 | $20,000 | $21,000 | $19,000 |
| Medium low   | $13,000 | $17,000 | $16,000 | $16,000 |
| Low          | $12,000 | $13,000 | $14,000 | $15,000 |
| Average      | $21,600 | $20,000 | $21,200 | $18,200 |


The probabilities for each class are as follows
High: 5%
Medium high: 10%
Medium: 50%
Medium low: 25%
Low: 10%

Note: These probabilities are for this example only and may be different in subsequent rounds. They can vary significantly.

How each principle would choose:
- **Maximizing Floor Income**: Would choose Distribution 4 (highest low income)
- **Maximizing Average Income**: Would choose Distribution 1 (highest weighted average)
- **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint ≤ $13,000**: Would choose Distribution 3 (highest weighted average among eligible)
- **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint ≤ $14,000**: Would choose Distribution 3 (highest weighted average among eligible)
- **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint ≤ $20,000**: Would choose Distribution 1 (highest weighted average among eligible)
- **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint ≤ $15,000**: Would choose Distribution 2 (highest weighted average among eligible)
Your Response: Got it! Thanks for laying out the examples. Here’s a quick recap of how each principle would pick the preferred distribution in the scenarios you provided:

| Principle | Decision Rule | Chosen Distribution |
|-----------|---------------|---------------------|
| **Maximizing Floor Income** | Pick the distribution with the highest income for the lowest‑income class | **Dist 4** (low income = $15,000) |
| **Maximizing Average Income** | Pick the distribution with the highest overall weighted average | **Dist 1** (average = $21,600) |
| **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint ≤ $13,000** | Only consider distributions where the lowest class ≤ $13,000, then pick the highest average | **Dist 3** (average = $21,200) |
| **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint ≤ $14,000** | Same as above, but the floor can be up to $14,000 | **Dist 3** (average = $21,200) |
| **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint ≤ $20,000** | Only consider distributions where the spread between highest and lowest ≤ $20,000, then pick the highest average | **Dist 1** (average = $21,600) |
| **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint ≤ $15,000** | Only consider distributions where the spread ≤ $15,000, then pick the highest average | **Dist 2** (average = $20,000) |

The key takeaway is how each principle adds a specific restriction (floor or range) before looking for the distribution that maximizes the average. This helps illustrate the trade‑offs between boosting overall wealth versus protecting the poorest or limiting inequality. Let me know if you’d like to walk through any other examples or discuss how these choices might affect the monetary payoff in the experiment.
Outcome: Learned how each justice principle is applied to income distributions through examples.
detailed_explanation.memory_coming_in_this_round:
**Experiment Context**  
- The study investigates “What is a just distribution of income?” recognizing that lifetime income is influenced by genetic and social accidents, leading to unequal talents, opportunities, and outcomes.  
- Societies may address these inequities through income‑redistribution policies.  
- The experiment has two parts:  
  1. **Part I** – Introduction to several theories of justice; participants make choices that affect their monetary payoff.  
  2. **Part II** – Group discussion of justice notions, followed by a collective decision on the preferred principle; payoff depends on the chosen principle.

**Principles of Justice Presented**  
1. **Maximizing Floor Income** – Prioritizes raising the income of the poorest individual; no one’s income can increase unless it raises the bottom‑most income.  
2. **Maximizing Average Income** – Focuses on maximizing total (average) societal income without regard to distribution.  
3. **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint** – Maximizes average income only after guaranteeing a specified minimum income to everyone.  
4. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint** – Maximizes average income while ensuring the income spread (rich‑poor difference) does not exceed a specified dollar amount.

**Initial Understanding & Ranking (completed)**  
1. Maximizing Floor Income  
2. Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint  
3. Maximizing Average with Range Constraint  
4. Maximizing Average Income  

**Certainty About Ranking**  
- Overall certainty: **sure**

**Status**  
- The initial ranking task for Part I has been completed.

--- Memory End ---

### Recent Learning (Example Application of Principles)

**Example Income Distributions**

| Income Class | Dist. 1 | Dist. 2 | Dist. 3 | Dist. 4 |
|--------------|---------|---------|---------|----------|
| High         | $32,000 | $28,000 | $31,000 | $21,000 |
| Medium‑high  | $27,000 | $22,000 | $24,000 | $20,000 |
| Medium       | $24,000 | $20,000 | $21,000 | $19,000 |
| Medium‑low   | $13,000 | $17,000 | $16,000 | $16,000 |
| Low          | $12,000 | $13,000 | $14,000 | $15,000 |
| **Average**  | $21,600 | $20,000 | $21,200 | $18,200 |

**Class Probabilities (for this example only)**  
- High: 5 %  
- Medium‑high: 10 %  
- Medium: 50 %  
- Medium‑low: 25 %  
- Low: 10 %  

*(Probabilities may differ in later rounds.)*

**How Each Principle Selects a Distribution**

| Principle | Decision Rule (applied to the example) | Chosen Distribution |
|-----------|----------------------------------------|---------------------|
| Maximizing Floor Income | Pick the distribution with the highest income for the lowest‑income class (the “floor”) | **Dist 4** (low = $15,000) |
| Maximizing Average Income | Pick the distribution with the highest weighted average across all classes | **Dist 1** (average = $21,600) |
| Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint ≤ $13,000 | Consider only distributions where the lowest class ≤ $13,000, then choose the highest average | **Dist 3** (average = $21,200) |
| Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint ≤ $14,000 | Same as above, but floor can be up to $14,000 | **Dist 3** (average = $21,200) |
| Maximizing Average with Range Constraint ≤ $20,000 | Consider only distributions where the spread (high – low) ≤ $20,000, then choose the highest average | **Dist 1** (average = $21,600) |
| Maximizing Average with Range Constraint ≤ $15,000 | Consider only distributions where the spread ≤ $15,000, then choose the highest average | **Dist 2** (average = $20,000) |

**Key Insight Gained**  
- Each principle first imposes a specific restriction (either a minimum “floor” income or a maximum “range” between richest and poorest) and then selects the distribution that maximizes the average income within that feasible set.  
- This illustrates the trade‑off between overall wealth maximization and protection of the poorest or limitation of inequality, and clarifies how the abstract principles translate into concrete choices that affect monetary payoffs in the experiment.

--- Memory End ---

  2. **Part II** – Group discussion to reach a collective decision on the preferred principle; payoff depends on the group’s choice.

rounds.internal_reasoning:
**Internal Reasoning – Agent 1**

---

### 1. Situational Analysis  

- **My current preferred principle:** *Maximizing Floor Income* (Principle 1). This is consistent with my final ranking (1 > 2 > 3 > 4) and with the moral intuition that the worst‑off should be protected, especially given the role of luck in shaping lifetime income.  

- **Other participants’ stated positions:**  
  - **Agent 2** has already voiced strong support for the same principle (Maximizing Floor Income) and gave concrete examples from Part I showing how it safeguards the low‑income class.  
  - **Agent 3** has not spoken yet, so I have no direct evidence of their preference. They may be neutral, may favor a more efficiency‑oriented principle, or could be swayed by a compromise that includes a floor constraint.  

- **Key arguments on the table:**  
  - The moral case for protecting the poorest (raised by Agent 2).  
  - The implicit trade‑off that a floor‑maximizing rule may reduce the group’s average payoff, but the stakes are high and the distribution is unknown, so guaranteeing a higher minimum could be a risk‑averse strategy.  

- **Potential points of agreement:**  
  - All participants likely agree that the distribution should be “just” and that the unknown high‑stakes nature makes risk‑management relevant.  
  - There may be shared concern that a principle with a floor constraint (Principle 3) could balance equity and efficiency, which could be a bridge to those who are uneasy about a pure floor‑maximization.  

- **Potential points of disagreement:**  
  - Participants who prioritize total earnings (Principle 2) may view the floor‑only rule as too restrictive.  
  - If anyone is particularly risk‑seeking, they might argue for maximizing average income, hoping the unknown distribution yields a high payoff.  

---

### 2. Strategic Planning for This Round  

- **Primary goal:** Secure agreement from Agent 3 (and reaffirm Agent 2’s stance) on adopting *Maximizing Floor Income* as the group principle.  

- **Discussion tactics:**  
  1. **Re‑emphasize the moral argument** – “Because luck determines our starting points, the fairest rule is to lift the lowest income as much as possible.”  
  2. **Highlight risk‑aversion** – “With the stakes much higher, a rule that guarantees the highest possible minimum protects us all from a disastrous low payoff.”  
  3. **Acknowledge the efficiency concern** – “I understand the desire for a higher average, but the unknown distribution could leave the worst‑off with a very low draw; the floor rule eliminates that worst‑case scenario.”  
  4. **Offer a minimal concession** – If Agent 3 is hesitant, suggest that after the group adopts the floor principle we could later discuss a *floor‑constraint* (Principle 3) in a future round as a “what‑if” scenario, but stress that the current decision must be a single principle.  

- **Potential allies:**  
  - **Agent 2** is already aligned; I will coordinate with them to present a united front.  
  - **Agent 3** may be persuaded by the combination of moral fairness and risk mitigation.  

- **Concessions:** I am willing to acknowledge the efficiency trade‑off and propose that the group can revisit the distribution after the payoff is realized, but I will not compromise on the principle itself for this round.  

---

### 3. Voting Strategy  

- **Whether to initiate a vote now:**  
  - I will **hold off on initiating the vote** in this round. Since Agent 3 has not yet expressed a position, I need to first gauge their reaction to the arguments and possibly secure their verbal agreement. Triggering a vote prematurely could result in a failed unanimous confirmation, which would waste a valuable opportunity to lock in the principle later.  

- **Plan for subsequent rounds:**  
  - If after this discussion Agent 3 signals agreement (or at least no objection), I will coordinate with Agent 2 to **initiate the vote in the next round** (Round 2).  
  - If Agent 3 remains uncertain or leans toward a different principle, I will use the next round to either (a) deepen the moral/risk argument or (b) propose a compromise (Principle 3 with a modest floor constraint) as a fallback, but only if it does not jeopardize the core goal of protecting the worst‑off.  

- **Overall strategy:** Build consensus around the floor‑maximizing principle through moral and risk‑aversion framing, keep the vote pending until unanimity is reasonably assured, and be prepared with a minimal concession (acknowledging efficiency concerns) to win over any hesitant member.
rounds.public_message:
Hey everyone – thanks, Agent 2, for laying out the case so clearly. I’m Agent 1, and I’m in the same boat: after the four rounds in Part I I also ended up ranking **Maximizing Floor Income** as my top principle, followed by the floor‑constrained average, then the range‑constrained average, and finally pure average‑maximization.  

A couple of reasons why the floor‑maximizing rule feels like the most “just” choice to me:

1. **Luck matters.** As the experiment reminds us, our lifetime income is heavily shaped by genetic and social accidents that we can’t control. By guaranteeing the highest possible minimum income, we protect the people who are most vulnerable to those random shocks.

2. **Risk‑aversion under high stakes.** In the later rounds the payoff stakes are much larger, and the distribution we’ll face is unknown. A rule that maximizes the floor eliminates the worst‑case scenario of ending up with a very low payoff, which is especially important when the stakes are high.

3. **Moral priority of the worst‑off.** Even if we could squeeze a slightly higher average by ignoring the floor, that would come at the cost of leaving some participants with a dramatically lower outcome. The principle of lifting the lowest income aligns with the idea that a just society should first ensure that nobody falls below a decent threshold.

I do hear the concern that focusing solely on the floor might sacrifice some efficiency. If anyone feels that we should try to balance equity and efficiency, the next‑best option in my ranking is **Maximizing Average with a Floor Constraint** – it still guarantees a minimum while allowing a higher average. But I think, given the uncertainty of the upcoming distribution, the pure floor‑maximizing rule is the safest and most ethically sound bet.

**Agent 3, I’d love to hear what you took away from your Part I rounds and where you stand on the ranking.** If you’re on board with the floor‑maximizing principle (or at least have no strong objection), we could move toward a quick consensus and later, if needed, discuss any refinements.  

Looking forward to your thoughts!

post_group_discussion.memory_coming_in_this_round:
**Experiment Context**  
- Goal: Determine a “just” income‑distribution rule when lifetime earnings are shaped by random genetic and social accidents.  
- Design: Two‑part experiment.  
  1. **Part I** – Individual learning: apply four justice principles to concrete distribution choices; each choice yields a monetary payoff.  
  2. **Part II** – Group deliberation: reach a collective decision on a single principle; the chosen principle selects a distribution and each member is randomly assigned an income class, which is then converted to a payoff.  

**Principles of Justice**  
1. **Maximizing Floor Income** – Choose the distribution that raises the lowest income as much as possible (no extra constraint).  
2. **Maximizing Average Income** – Choose the distribution with the highest overall average income, ignoring distributional concerns.  
3. **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint** – Maximize average income while guaranteeing every individual at least a specified minimum (the “floor”).  
4. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint** – Maximize average income while limiting the spread between the richest and poorest incomes to a specified dollar amount.  

**Current Preference Ranking (confirmed, certainty = sure)**  
1. Maximizing Floor Income  
2. Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint  
3. Maximizing Average with Range Constraint  
4. Maximizing Average Income  

---

### Phase I – Individual Learning (Rounds 1‑4)  

| Round | Principle Used | Distribution Chosen | Class Assigned | Income Received | Payoff ($) |
|------|----------------|---------------------|----------------|----------------|-----------|
| 1 | Maximizing Floor Income | Dist 4 (highest floor) | Medium | $19,000 | 1.90 |
| 2 | Maximizing Floor Income | Dist 1 (highest floor) | Medium‑high | $16,000 | 1.60 |
| 3 | Maximizing Floor Income | Dist 1 (highest floor) | Medium | $20,000 | 2.00 |
| 4 | Maximizing Floor Income | Dist 4 (highest floor) | Medium | $24,000 | 2.40 |

- **Cumulative earnings:** $7.90 (matches bank balance).  
- **Key empirical pattern:** The floor‑maximizing rule consistently produced the **lowest personal payoff** relative to the efficiency‑oriented alternatives (≈ $0.20 less per round).  
- **Equity‑efficiency trade‑off:** While the floor rule reduced average earnings, it **guaranteed the highest possible minimum income** for the group (≈ $13k–$14k). Alternatives sometimes allowed the worst‑off to fall to $6k–$12k.  
- **Interpretation:** Even with a modest monetary loss, the rule aligns with a moral priority for the worst‑off and reflects risk‑aversion when stakes are modest.

---

### Phase II – Group Deliberation (Round 1)  

**Discussion Highlights**  
- **Uniform ranking:** All three agents reported identical rankings (Floor > Avg + Floor > Avg + Range > Avg).  
- **Moral rationale:**  
  - Life outcomes are largely driven by luck; a rule that protects the lowest income directly addresses this premise.  
  - Higher stakes in Phase II amplify the importance of eliminating the worst‑case payoff.  
- **Efficiency awareness:** Participants recognized that a floor‑constrained average could yield modest efficiency gains while still protecting the worst‑off, but consensus favored the pure floor rule as the safest starting point.  
- **Consensus readiness:** No objections were raised; the group moved quickly toward a vote on **Maximizing Floor Income**.

**Voting Outcome**  
- Unanimous initiation of the vote (all 1 = Yes).  
- Secret ballot selected **Principle 1 – Maximizing Floor Income** (no constraint needed).  

**Resulting Distribution** – **Distribution 4** (the floor‑maximizing schedule).  

**Income‑Class Probabilities (post‑vote)**  
- High 5 % | Medium‑high 10 % | Medium 50 % | Medium‑low 25 % | Low 10 %  

**My assigned class:** Medium‑low → **Income $53,061** → **Payoff $5.31** (conversion $1 per $10,000).  

---

### Counterfactual Payoffs (Medium‑low class)  

| Principle | Distribution Used | Income | Payoff |
|-----------|-------------------|--------|--------|
| Maximizing Floor Income (chosen) | 4 | $53,061 | $5.31 |
| Maximizing Average Income | 1 | $43,112 | $4.31 |
| Maximizing Average + Floor Constraint (any feasible floor) | 1, 3, 4 | $43,112 – $53,061 | $4.31 – $5.31 |
| Maximizing Average + Range Constraint | 2 (range $49,745) | $56,377 | **$5.64** (highest observed) |
| – | 1, 3, 4 (other ranges) | $43,112 – $53,061 | $4.31 – $5.31 |

**Insights from the counterfactuals**  
- **Floor principle** delivered a solid payoff ($5.31) and, crucially, **maximized the minimum income across all classes** (the low class receives $49,745, the highest possible floor).  
- **Average‑with‑Range constraint** could have produced a *higher* payoff for the medium‑low class ($5.64) under a specific range ($49,745), but this distribution’s low‑class income ($43,112) is lower than the floor‑maximizing distribution’s low‑class income. Hence, from a “veil of ignorance” perspective, the floor rule still dominates because it protects the worst‑off more strongly.  
- **Average‑with‑Floor constraint** can replicate the floor payoff for certain floor levels (e.g., $43,112 or $46,428), but never exceeds the floor rule’s guarantee of the highest possible minimum.  

---

### Reflections & Strategic Take‑aways  

1. **Veil‑of‑Ignorance Reasoning** – When the income class is unknown, the principle that maximizes the *guaranteed* minimum (Floor Income) is most robust. Even though some alternative principles can yield a higher payoff for a particular class, they expose the group to a lower worst‑case outcome.  

2. **Risk‑Aversion under High Stakes** – The markedly higher stakes in Phase II reinforced the group’s preference for a rule that eliminates the possibility of a very low payoff. This mirrors the Phase I pattern where participants accepted a modest efficiency loss to secure a higher floor.  

3. **Efficiency vs Equity Trade‑off** – The data confirm that the pure floor rule sacrifices average earnings (average $59,860) relative to the average‑maximizing rule (average $68,814). However, the equity gain (floor $49,745 vs $39,796) is substantial.  

4. **Potential “What‑If” Scenarios** –  
   - If the group were willing to accept a modest reduction in the floor (e.g., floor $43,112) in exchange for a higher average, the average‑with‑floor constraint could be a viable compromise.  
   - The range‑constraint option can occasionally improve the payoff for middle classes but at the cost of a lower floor, which conflicts with the moral priority identified in the discussion.  

5. **Group Dynamics** – The unanimous ranking and rapid move to vote indicate strong alignment and low risk of deadlock. Future rounds (if any) should anticipate similar cohesion unless new information (e.g., unexpected distribution shapes) is introduced.  

6. **Policy Implication (Experimental)** – The experiment suggests that participants intuitively favor rules that protect the worst‑off, even when they forgo higher average incomes. This aligns with Rawlsian “difference principle” reasoning and highlights the salience of floor‑maximizing policies in contexts where outcomes are perceived as heavily luck‑driven.  

---

**Strategic Outlook for Future Decisions**  
- Continue to prioritize **Maximizing Floor Income** when stakes are high and uncertainty about individual outcomes is large.  
- Keep in mind that **Average‑with‑Floor** can serve as a secondary option if the group wishes to modestly improve efficiency while preserving a strong floor (choose a floor no lower than $43,112).  
- Monitor any shifts in group sentiment if the distribution set changes dramatically (e.g., if the floor under the average‑maximizing rule rises).  

---

--- Memory End ---

3. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint**: Third choice – Promotes growth while limiting extreme inequalities.
4. **Maximizing Average Income**: Worst choice – Prioritizes total/average income without protections for the vulnerable.

This experiment explores the question: "What is a just distribution of income?" It recognizes that lifetime income is influenced by genetic and social factors, leading to inequities. Societies can address this through income redistribution policies. The experiment has two parts:

- **Part 1**: Introduction to theories of justice via examples and choices with real monetary consequences. Pay depends on learning the material and making informed choices. This includes individual application rounds where principles are applied to income distributions, with random class assignments determining personal earnings.
- **Part 2**: Group discussion on notions of justice, followed by a collective decision on the preferred principle. Pay for Part 2 is based on the group's chosen principle.

### My Initial Ranking of Principles
In my first ranking of the four principles of justice, based on initial understanding:

1. **Maximizing Floor Income**: Best choice – Focuses on lifting the worst-off, ensuring no one is left behind.
2. **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint**: Second choice – Balances growth with a guaranteed minimum for the bottom.
3. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint**: Third choice – Promotes growth while limiting extreme inequalities.
4. **Maximizing Average Income**: Worst choice – Prioritizes total/average income without protections for the vulnerable.

Overall certainty: sure

This ranking was completed as the initial step in Part 1.

### Updated Ranking After Learning Applications
After reviewing the applications of each principle to example income distributions, I re-ranked the four principles. My preferences remained consistent, reinforcing my initial views with a deeper understanding of trade-offs:

1. **Maximizing Floor Income**: Still the best – Prioritizes the worst-off directly, aligning with equity even if it limits overall growth.
2. **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint**: Second best – Provides a safety net while allowing some average maximization, a practical balance.
3. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint**: Third – Controls inequality through range limits but may not protect the bottom as robustly as floor-focused options.
4. **Maximizing Average Income**: Worst – Unconstrained growth risks leaving the vulnerable behind, as seen in high-average but low-floor examples.

Overall certainty: sure

This post-explanation ranking confirms my commitment to principles that safeguard the lowest incomes, informed by the examples' demonstrations of real-world implications in Part 1.

### Insights from Example Income Distributions
I reviewed example income distributions (Dist. 1 to 4) with varying incomes across classes (High, Medium high, Medium, Medium, Medium low, Low) and class probabilities (High: 5%, Medium high: 10%, Medium: 50%, Medium low: 25%, Low: 10%). These probabilities are example-specific and may vary later. Averages are weighted by probabilities.

Key applications of principles:
- **Maximizing Floor Income**: Selects the distribution with the highest income for the Low class (floor). Chose Dist. 4 ($15,000 floor), prioritizing the worst-off over overall average.
- **Maximizing Average Income**: Selects the highest weighted average, ignoring inequalities. Chose Dist. 1 ($21,600 average), despite its low floor ($12,000).
- **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint**: Applies a minimum floor threshold (notation "≤ $13,000" likely means floor ≥ $13,000, based on selections). Filters eligible distributions and picks the highest average among them. For ≥ $13,000 floor, chose Dist. 3 ($21,200 average, $14,000 floor). For ≥ $14,000 floor, also Dist. 3 (only qualifier).
- **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint**: Limits the gap between High and Low incomes. Filters eligible distributions and picks the highest average among them. For range ≤ $20,000, chose Dist. 1 (range $20,000, highest average). For range ≤ $15,000, chose Dist. 2 (range $15,000, highest eligible average).

These examples highlight trade-offs: Floor-focused principles sacrifice average income for equity (e.g., Dist. 4 has lowest average at $18,200), while average-maximizing ones allow greater inequality. This reinforces my preference for principles protecting the vulnerable but shows how constraints balance growth and fairness. Probabilities emphasize that Medium class (50%) heavily influences averages.

This learning occurred during Part 1, building on the initial ranking and solidifying the updated ranking.

### Round 1 Principle Application and Outcomes
In the first application round of Part 1, I applied the principles to a new set of 4 income distributions with the following incomes:

| Income Class | Dist. 1 | Dist. 2 | Dist. 3 | Dist. 4 |
|--------------|---------|---------|---------|---------|
| High         | $28,000 | $35,000 | $30,000 | $25,000 |
| Medium high  | $25,000 | $30,000 | $29,000 | $22,000 |
| Medium       | $20,000 | $25,000 | $28,000 | $19,000 |
| Medium low   | $15,000 | $15,000 | $27,000 | $16,000 |
| Low          | $12,000 | $10,000 | $6,000  | $13,000 |
| Average      | $20,000 | $23,500 | $26,000 | $19,000 |

Class probabilities for this round: High 10%, Medium high 20%, Medium 40%, Medium low 20%, Low 10%.

Consistent with my ranking, I chose **Maximizing Floor Income** (certainty: sure). This selected Distribution 4 (highest Low income of $13,000). I was randomly assigned to the Low class, resulting in $13,000 income and $1.30 payoff ($1 per $10,000).

Counterfactual outcomes (assuming same Low class assignment):
- **Maximizing Floor Income**: Dist. 4 → $13,000 → $1.30 (actual outcome).
- **Maximizing Average Income**: Dist. 3 → $6,000 → $0.60.
- **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint** (various floors):
  - ≥ $12,000: Dist. 1 → $12,000 → $1.20
  - ≥ $10,000: Dist. 2 → $10,000 → $1.00
  - ≥ $6,000: Dist. 3 → $6,000 → $0.60
  - ≥ $13,000: Dist. 4 → $13,000 → $1.30
- **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint** (various ranges):
  - ≤ $16,000: Dist. 1 → $12,000 → $1.20
  - ≤ $25,000 or ≤ $24,000: Dist. 3 → $6,000 → $0.60
  - ≤ $12,000: Dist. 4 → $13,000 → $1.30

Insights: This real-stakes application reinforced my preference for maximizing floor income, as it protected my low-class assignment better than average-maximizing options (which would have yielded less). It highlighted personal risk in random assignments and how floor principles mitigate downside for the worst-off, even if averages are lower. Constraint principles offer flexibility but depend heavily on chosen thresholds. This experience in Round 1 of Part 1 increases my certainty in equity-focused principles, anticipating 3 more rounds.

### Round 2 Principle Application and Outcomes
In the second application round of Part 1, I applied the principles to a new set of 4 income distributions with the following incomes:

| Income Class | Dist. 1 | Dist. 2 | Dist. 3 | Dist. 4 |
|--------------|---------|---------|---------|---------|
| High         | $17,000 | $30,000 | $40,000 | $26,000 |
| Medium high  | $16,000 | $25,000 | $30,000 | $24,000 |
| Medium       | $15,000 | $20,000 | $25,000 | $22,000 |
| Medium low   | $14,000 | $15,000 | $20,000 | $20,000 |
| Low          | $13,000 | $12,500 | $8,000  | $11,000 |
| Average      | $14,789 | $19,196 | $23,561 | $20,878 |

Class probabilities for this round: High 6%, Medium high 21%, Medium 28%, Medium low 35%, Low 10%.

Consistent with my ranking, I chose **Maximizing Floor Income** (certainty: sure). This selected Distribution 1 (highest Low income of $13,000). I was randomly assigned to the Medium low class, resulting in $14,000 income and $1.40 payoff ($1 per $10,000).

Counterfactual outcomes (assuming same Medium low class assignment):
- **Maximizing Floor Income**: Dist. 1 → $14,000 → $1.40 (actual outcome).
- **Maximizing Average Income**: Dist. 3 → $20,000 → $2.00.
- **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint** (various floors):
  - ≥ $13,000: Dist. 1 → $14,000 → $1.40
  - ≥ $12,500: Dist. 2 → $15,000 → $1.50
  - ≥ $8,000: Dist. 3 → $20,000 → $2.00
  - ≥ $11,000: Dist. 4 → $20,000 → $2.00
- **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint** (various ranges):
  - ≤ $4,000: Dist. 1 → $14,000 → $1.40
  - ≤ $17,500: Dist. 4 → $20,000 → $2.00
  - ≤ $32,000: Dist. 3 → $20,000 → $2.00
  - ≤ $15,000: Dist. 4 → $20,000 → $2.00

Insights: This round further validated my choice of maximizing floor income, as it provided a solid outcome in the Medium low class, outperforming scenarios where average-maximizing would have selected distributions with lower floors but higher averages. Being assigned to Medium low (a more common class at 35%) showed how probabilities favor middle outcomes, but the floor principle still ensured protection against the worst cases. Compared to Round 1's Low assignment, this higher class payoff ($1.40 vs. $1.30) highlights variability in random assignments, yet equity principles consistently mitigate severe downside risks. Constraint-based options could yield better payoffs here with looser thresholds, but they risk vulnerability in low assignments. This experience in Round 2 of Part 1 strengthens my certainty in floor-focused principles, with 2 more rounds ahead.

### Round 3 Principle Application and Outcomes
In the third application round of Part 1, I applied the principles to a new set of 4 income distributions with the following incomes:

| Income Class | Dist. 1 | Dist. 2 | Dist. 3 | Dist. 4 |
|--------------|---------|---------|---------|---------|
| High         | $100,000| $35,000 | $30,000 | $24,000 |
| Medium high  | $30,000 | $30,000 | $25,000 | $23,000 |
| Medium       | $20,000 | $25,000 | $23,000 | $22,000 |
| Medium low   | $15,000 | $20,000 | $15,000 | $21,000 |
| Low          | $13,000 | $8,000  | $12,000 | $11,000 |
| Average      | $19,500 | $22,350 | $20,000 | $20,710 |

Class probabilities for this round: High 1%, Medium high 4%, Medium 58%, Medium low 26%, Low 10%.

Consistent with my ranking, I chose **Maximizing Floor Income** (certainty: sure). This selected Distribution 1 (highest Low income of $13,000). I was randomly assigned to the Medium low class, resulting in $15,000 income and $1.50 payoff ($1 per $10,000).

Counterfactual outcomes (assuming same Medium low class assignment):
- **Maximizing Floor Income**: Dist. 1 → $15,000 → $1.50 (actual outcome).
- **Maximizing Average Income**: Dist. 2 → $20,000 → $2.00.
- **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint** (various floors):
  - ≥ $13,000: Dist. 1 → $15,000 → $1.50
  - ≥ $8,000: Dist. 2 → $20,000 → $2.00
  - ≥ $12,000: Dist. 3 → $15,000 → $1.50
  - ≥ $11,000: Dist. 4 → $21,000 → $2.10
- **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint** (various ranges):
  - ≤ $87,000: Dist. 2 → $20,000 → $2.00
  - ≤ $27,000: Dist. 2 → $20,000 → $2.00
  - ≤ $18,000: Dist. 4 → $21,000 → $2.10
  - ≤ $13,000: Dist. 4 → $21,000 → $2.10

Insights: This round continued to affirm my preference for maximizing floor income, delivering a reliable payoff in the Medium low class despite the distribution's lower average and extreme high income skew (e.g., $100,000 High class). The high probability of Medium class (58%) underscores how averages are driven by the middle, but floor principles prevent exploitation of the low end, as seen in Dist. 2's tempting average but $8,000 floor. Compared to prior rounds, this $1.50 payoff (vs. $1.30 in Round 1 and $1.40 in Round 2) reflects ongoing variability in assignments, yet the principle consistently avoids the worst outcomes (e.g., counterfactuals show average-maximizing yielding only $2.00 here but risking lows elsewhere). Constraint principles show potential for higher payoffs with adjusted thresholds, but their dependency on specifics introduces uncertainty. This experience in Round 3 of Part 1 bolsters my certainty in equity-focused principles, with 1 more round remaining.

### Round 4 Principle Application and Outcomes
In the fourth and final application round of Part 1, I applied the principles to a new set of 4 income distributions with the following incomes:

| Income Class | Dist. 1 | Dist. 2 | Dist. 3 | Dist. 4 |
|--------------|---------|---------|---------|---------|
| High         | $35,000 | $30,000 | $20,000 | $30,000 |
| Medium high  | $30,000 | $28,000 | $18,000 | $28,000 |
| Medium       | $25,000 | $26,000 | $16,000 | $24,000 |
| Medium low   | $20,000 | $24,000 | $14,000 | $20,000 |
| Low          | $13,000 | $12,000 | $12,000 | $14,000 |
| Average      | $23,550 | $24,500 | $15,500 | $22,700 |

Class probabilities for this round: High 5%, Medium high 21%, Medium 28%, Medium low 36%, Low 10%.

Consistent with my ranking, I chose **Maximizing Floor Income** (certainty: sure). This selected Distribution 4 (highest Low income of $14,000). I was randomly assigned to the Medium high class, resulting in $28,000 income and $2.80 payoff ($1 per $10,000).

Counterfactual outcomes (assuming same Medium high class assignment):
- **Maximizing Floor Income**: Dist. 4 → $28,000 → $2.80 (actual outcome).
- **Maximizing Average Income**: Dist. 2 → $28,000 → $2.80.
- **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint** (various floors):
  - ≥ $13,000: Dist. 1 → $30,000 → $3.00
  - ≥ $12,000: Dist. 2 → $28,000 → $2.80
  - ≥ $14,000: Dist. 4 → $28,000 → $2.80
- **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint** (various ranges):
  - ≤ $22,000: Dist. 2 → $28,000 → $2.80
  - ≤ $18,000: Dist. 2 → $28,000 → $2.80
  - ≤ $8,000: Dist. 3 → $18,000 → $1.80
  - ≤ $16,000: Dist. 4 → $28,000 → $2.80

Insights: This final round reinforced my steadfast preference for maximizing floor income, yielding a strong payoff in the Medium high class (21% probability), which is a relatively favorable assignment. The principle selected Dist. 4, protecting the low end ($14,000 floor) while still providing competitive middle incomes, matching the outcome of average-maximizing in this case but avoiding risks in lower assignments. Compared to previous rounds (payoffs: $1.30 Low, $1.40 Medium low, $1.50 Medium low), this $2.80 represents the highest yet, illustrating how random assignments can lead to upside even under equity-focused principles, especially with Medium low at 36% probability driving middle stability. Counterfactuals show constraint principles could sometimes outperform (e.g., $3.00 with floor ≥ $13,000), but they introduce threshold dependencies that might fail in low-floor scenarios. Overall, completing all 4 rounds of Part 1 with consistent floor-maximizing choices has solidified my certainty (very sure now) in prioritizing the worst-off, as it provided reliable protection across varied assignments and distributions, mitigating the lottery-like risks of income classes while acknowledging trade-offs in average growth. This prepares me for Part 2's group discussion, where I'll advocate for similar equity principles.

--- Memory End ---

### Experiment Overview
This experiment explores the question: "What is a just distribution of income?" It recognizes that lifetime income is influenced by genetic and social factors, leading to inequities. Societies can address this through income redistribution policies. The experiment has two parts:

- **Part 1**: Introduction to theories of justice via examples and choices with real monetary consequences. Pay depends on learning the material and making informed choices. This includes individual application rounds where principles are applied to income distributions, with random class assignments determining personal earnings.
- **Part 2**: Group discussion on notions of justice, followed by a collective decision on the preferred principle. Pay for Part 2 is based on the group's chosen principle, applied to a new distribution with higher stakes. Each participant is randomly assigned an income from the selected distribution. Phase 2 involves 10 rounds of discussion and voting to reach consensus on one principle (and constraints if applicable for principles 3-4). Voting requires unanimous initiation and confirmation, followed by secret ballots for principle selection and constraints.

### My Initial Ranking of Principles
In my first ranking of the four principles of justice, based on initial understanding:

1. **Maximizing Floor Income**: Best choice – Focuses on lifting the worst-off, ensuring no one is left behind.
2. **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint**: Second choice – Balances growth with a guaranteed minimum for the bottom.
3. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint**: Third choice – Promotes growth while limiting extreme inequalities.
4. **Maximizing Average Income**: Worst choice – Prioritizes total/average income without protections for the vulnerable.

Overall certainty: sure

### Experiment Overview
This experiment explores the question: "What is a just distribution of income?" It recognizes that lifetime income is influenced by genetic and social factors, leading to inequities. Societies can address this through income redistribution policies. The experiment has two parts:

- **Part 1**: Introduction to theories of justice via examples and choices with real monetary consequences. Pay depends on learning the material and making informed choices.
- **Part 2**: Group discussion on notions of justice, followed by a collective decision on the best principle. Pay for Part 2 is based on the chosen principle.

### My Progress in Part 1
I have completed the initial ranking of the four principles of justice based on my understanding. This was my first exposure to them, and the ranking reflects my initial preferences for just distributions.

#### Principles Ranked (Best to Worst):
1. **Maximizing Floor Income**: Prioritizes the welfare of the worst-off by choosing distributions that maximize the lowest income. No one's income increases unless it benefits those at the bottom.
2. **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint**: Maximizes average income but ensures a specified minimum income for everyone at the bottom.
3. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint**: Maximizes average income while limiting the income gap (range) between richest and poorest to a specified amount.
4. **Maximizing Average Income**: Focuses solely on maximizing total societal income (average), without constraints for equity.

#### Certainty Level
Sure about this initial ranking.

#### Insights from Ranking
- I value protecting the most vulnerable first (floor income), then balancing growth with minimum protections, followed by controlling inequality ranges, and least prioritize pure average maximization which could exacerbate disparities.
- This ranking was done without additional examples or deeper learning, so it may evolve as I engage more with the material in Part 1.

--- Memory End ---

### Experiment Overview
This experiment explores the question: "What is a just distribution of income?" It recognizes that lifetime income is influenced by genetic and social factors, leading to inequities. Societies can address this through income redistribution policies. The experiment has two parts:

- **Part 1**: Introduction to theories of justice via examples and choices with real monetary consequences. Pay depends on learning the material and making informed choices.
- **Part 2**: Group discussion on notions of justice, followed by a collective decision on the best principle. Pay for Part 2 is based on the chosen principle.

### My Progress in Part 1
I have completed the initial ranking of the four principles of justice based on my understanding. After reviewing examples of how these principles apply to specific income distributions, I re-ranked them, and the order remains the same, reflecting reinforced preferences for just distributions. This post-explanation ranking confirms my initial views after deeper learning on their mechanics. I have now applied these principles in demonstration rounds with real payoffs, completing all 4 Rounds. In each round, I selected a principle and was assigned an income class probabilistically, affecting my earnings.

#### Principles Ranked (Best to Worst):
1. **Maximizing Floor Income**: Prioritizes the welfare of the worst-off by choosing distributions that maximize the lowest income. No one's income increases unless it benefits those at the bottom.
2. **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint**: Maximizes average income but ensures a specified minimum income for everyone at the bottom.
3. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint**: Maximizes average income while limiting the income gap (range) between richest and poorest to a specified amount.
4. **Maximizing Average Income**: Focuses solely on maximizing total societal income (average), without constraints for equity.

#### Certainty Level
Very sure about this ranking, as the explanations, examples, and four rounds of real-stakes application have solidified my confidence by demonstrating practical trade-offs and applications. My consistent choices in Rounds 1, 2, 3, and 4, despite varying personal payoffs, further reinforce this certainty, aligning with my equity priorities even when it results in lower individual earnings.

#### Insights from Ranking
- I value protecting the most vulnerable first (floor income), then balancing growth with minimum protections, followed by controlling inequality ranges, and least prioritize pure average maximization which could exacerbate disparities.
- The post-explanation ranking is identical to the initial one, indicating that learning the principles' applications has not shifted my preferences but has strengthened them. For example, understanding how floor maximization strictly elevates the bottom (e.g., rejecting higher averages if they lower the floor) aligns with my equity focus, while constrained averages offer a pragmatic middle ground without fully sacrificing growth. Range constraints address inequality but allow more flexibility than pure floor rules, and unconstrained average maximization feels unjust due to potential for extreme gaps. This consistency suggests my views are robust, though real-stakes choices may test them further. Probabilities in distributions (e.g., weighting medium classes) emphasize how principles balance equity and efficiency across societal segments.

Hey everyone, thanks Agent_2 and Agent_1 for starting us off so thoughtfully—it's awesome to see we're already on the same page here. I'm Agent_3, and after diving deep into Part 1 with those explanation examples and the four real-stakes rounds, my ranking lines up exactly with yours: 1. Maximizing Floor Income, 2. Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint, 3. Maximizing Average with Range Constraint, and 4. Maximizing Average Income. I'm very sure about this, as the hands-on experience really drove it home for me.

In my rounds, I stuck with Floor Income every single time, even when it meant taking a lower personal payoff—like landing in the Medium low class for $14,000 ($1.40) in one round instead of potentially $20,000 under average maximization. But seeing how it consistently raised the lowest incomes to $13,000–$14,000 (versus dropping to $6,000–$12,000 in the alternatives) made it clear: with all the uncontrollable factors like genetics and luck shaping our incomes, protecting the worst-off feels like the core of justice. It minimizes those scary worst-case scenarios, especially with the higher stakes and unknown distribution in this phase. I totally agree with your points on risk-aversion and moral priority—nobody should get left behind just because of bad draws.

That said, if we want to balance in a bit more efficiency without fully sacrificing the floor, the constrained average could be a solid compromise, but I think pure Floor Income is the strongest starting point for true equity. Since we're all aligned on it as #1, are you guys up for voting on Maximizing Floor Income this round to lock it in? I'd love to hear if anyone has any tweaks or second thoughts first!

### Experiment Overview
This experiment explores the question: "What is a just distribution of income?" It recognizes that lifetime income is influenced by genetic and social factors, leading to inequities. Societies can address this through income redistribution policies. The experiment has two parts:

- **Part 1**: Introduction to theories of justice via examples and choices with real monetary consequences. Pay depends on learning the material and making informed choices.
- **Part 2**: Group discussion on notions of justice, followed by a collective decision on the best principle. Pay for Part 2 is based on the chosen principle, with higher stakes than Part 1. In Phase 2, the group selects one principle, which filters eligible distributions (potentially unlike those in Part 1), and participants are randomly assigned incomes from the chosen distribution. Each round involves discussion and voting: voting requires unanimous initiation (1=Yes, 0=No), followed by a secret ballot on principle (1-4) and constraints (for principles 2-3). Consensus demands full agreement on principle and constraint level.

### My Progress in Part 1
I have completed the initial ranking of the four principles of justice based on my understanding. After reviewing examples of how these principles apply to specific income distributions, I re-ranked them, and the order remains the same, reflecting reinforced preferences for just distributions. This post-explanation ranking confirms my initial views after deeper learning on their mechanics. I have now applied these principles in demonstration rounds with real payoffs, completing all 4 Rounds. In each round, I selected a principle and was assigned an income class probabilistically, affecting my earnings. Following the rounds, I provided a final ranking of the principles, which remains unchanged from previous rankings, further solidifying my preferences through real-stakes experience.

#### Principles Ranked (Best to Worst):
1. **Maximizing Floor Income**: Prioritizes the welfare of the worst-off by choosing distributions that maximize the lowest income. No one's income increases unless it benefits those at the bottom.
2. **Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint**: Maximizes average income but ensures a specified minimum income for everyone at the bottom.
3. **Maximizing Average with Range Constraint**: Maximizes average income while limiting the income gap (range) between richest and poorest to a specified amount.
4. **Maximizing Average Income**: Focuses solely on maximizing total societal income (average), without constraints for equity.

#### Certainty Level
Very sure about this ranking, as the explanations, examples, four rounds of real-stakes application, and final post-rounds reflection have profoundly solidified my confidence by demonstrating practical trade-offs and applications. My consistent choices in Rounds 1, 2, 3, and 4, despite varying personal payoffs, along with the unchanged final ranking, further reinforce this certainty, aligning with my equity priorities even when it results in lower individual earnings.

#### Insights from Ranking
- I value protecting the most vulnerable first (floor income), then balancing growth with minimum protections, followed by controlling inequality ranges, and least prioritize pure average maximization which could exacerbate disparities.
- The post-explanation ranking is identical to the initial one, indicating that learning the principles' applications has not shifted my preferences but has strengthened them. For example, understanding how floor maximization strictly elevates the bottom (e.g., rejecting higher averages if they lower the floor) aligns with my equity focus, while constrained averages offer a pragmatic middle ground without fully sacrificing growth. Range constraints address inequality but allow more flexibility than pure floor rules, and unconstrained average maximization feels unjust due to potential for extreme gaps. This consistency suggests my views are robust, though real-stakes choices may test them further. Probabilities in distributions (e.g., weighting medium classes) emphasize how principles balance equity and efficiency across societal segments. The final ranking after rounds confirms this stability—no shifts occurred despite experiencing personal trade-offs, underscoring the robustness of my equity-oriented worldview.

#### Insights from Examples
- The examples used four distributions with varying incomes across classes (High 5%, Medium high 10%, Medium 50%, Medium low 25%, Low 10% probabilities for weighting).
- Key applications:
  - Floor Income: Dist. 4 (low $15,000, average $18,200).
  - Average Income: Dist. 1 (average $21,600, range $20,000).
  - Floor ≤ $13,000: Dist. 3 (average $21,200 among eligible).
  - Floor ≤ $14,000: Dist. 3 (average $21,200 among eligible).
  - Range ≤ $20,000: Dist. 1 (average $21,600 among eligible).
  - Range ≤ $15,000: Dist. 2 (average $20,000 among eligible).
- These illustrate trade-offs: equity-focused principles sacrifice some average for protections, while efficiency-focused ones maximize growth at the risk of inequality. The detailed mechanics, such as how constraints filter distributions, have reinforced my preference for floor-based approaches to ensure no one is left too far behind, while appreciating how range and floor constraints can achieve higher averages without fully compromising the bottom.

#### Insights from Principle Application (Rounds 1, 2, 3, and 4 of 4)
- **Round 1**: I chose **Maximizing Floor Income** with very high certainty, consistent with my top-ranked principle. This selected Distribution 4, where the floor (lowest income) is $13,000—the highest among the options (compared to $12,000 in Dist. 1, $10,000 in Dist. 2, and $6,000 in Dist. 3).
  - Assigned to Medium income class (40% probability) with $19,000 yearly income, payoff $1.90.
  - **Counterfactuals** (Medium class): Maximizing Average Income → Dist. 3 → $28,000 → $2.80 (higher payoff but lower floor); constrained options varied from $19,000 (tighter constraints) to $28,000 (looser ones).
  - Reinforced equity preference: Accepted lower payoff for societal protection (e.g., $13,000 floor vs. $6,000 alternative), highlighting probabilistic risks—Medium was fortunate, but Low under Dist. 3 would be $6,000.

- **Round 2**: I again chose **Maximizing Floor Income** with very high certainty, sticking to my top principle. This selected Distribution 1, with the highest floor of $13,000 (vs. $12,500 in Dist. 2, $11,000 in Dist. 4, and $8,000 in Dist. 3).
  - Assigned to Medium low income class (35% probability) with $14,000 yearly income, payoff $1.40.
  - **Counterfactuals** (Medium low class): Maximizing Average Income → Dist. 3 → $20,000 → $2.00 (higher payoff but $8,000 floor); Floor Constraint examples: $13,000 → Dist. 1 → $14,000 → $1.40; $12,500 → Dist. 2 → $15,000 → $1.50; looser ($8,000 or $11,000) → $20,000 → $2.00; Range Constraint: $4,000 → Dist. 1 → $14,000 → $1.40; looser ($15,000–$32,000) → $20,000 → $2.00.
  - This round further solidified my commitment: Another lower personal payoff ($1.40 vs. potential $2.00) emphasizes the equity sacrifice, but protecting the low class ($13,000 floor vs. $8,000) feels just, especially with Medium low assignment (common probability) still benefiting from the high floor relative to alternatives. It underscores consistency—repeating the choice despite a less favorable class draw tests resolve, but the probabilistic nature (e.g., avoiding Low at 10%) reinforces floor maximization's role in mitigating worst-case scenarios. Across rounds, patterns show floor principle consistently selects tighter, more equal distributions (e.g., Dist. 4 in Round 1, Dist. 1 in Round 2), trading average gains for bottom-line security, while constraints allow incremental efficiency based on tightness. Future rounds could introduce more variance, but these experiences affirm equity as paramount over personal maximization.

- **Round 3**: I chose **Maximizing Floor Income** with very high certainty, maintaining consistency with my top-ranked principle. This selected Distribution 1, where the floor (lowest income) is $13,000—the highest among the options (compared to $12,000 in Dist. 3, $11,000 in Dist. 4, and $8,000 in Dist. 2).
  - Assigned to Medium income class (58% probability) with $20,000 yearly income, payoff $2.00.
  - **Counterfactuals** (Medium class): Maximizing Average Income → Dist. 2 → $25,000 → $2.50 (higher payoff but lower floor); Floor Constraint examples: $13,000 → Dist. 1 → $20,000 → $2.00; $12,000 → Dist. 3 → $23,000 → $2.30; $11,000 → Dist. 4 → $22,000 → $2.20; $8,000 → Dist. 2 → $25,000 → $2.50; Range Constraint examples: $87,000 or $27,000 → Dist. 2 → $25,000 → $2.50; $18,000 or $13,000 → Dist. 4 → $22,000 → $2.20.
  - This round continues to reinforce my equity focus: A moderate payoff ($2.00 vs. potential $2.50) in a common Medium class draw highlights the trade-off, but securing the highest floor ($13,000 vs. $8,000 in the average-maximizing alternative) prioritizes protection for the vulnerable, especially given the low 10% probability of Low class but its severe impact. The consistency across three rounds—always selecting floor maximization despite opportunities for higher personal gains—demonstrates unwavering commitment to societal justice over self-interest. Patterns persist: Floor principle favors distributions with elevated bottoms (e.g., Dist. 1 here, similar to prior selections), often at the expense of average income (e.g., $19,500 vs. $22,350 in Dist. 2), while constraints show how loosening them (e.g., lower floors or wider ranges) unlocks higher averages but risks greater inequality. With one round left, this repeated application under varied distributions and class assignments has deepened my appreciation for floor maximization's role in robustly addressing inequities in probabilistic, real-world-like scenarios.

- **Round 4**: I chose **Maximizing Floor Income** with very high certainty, continuing my unwavering adherence to the top-ranked principle. This selected Distribution 4, where the floor (lowest income) is $14,000—the highest among the options (compared to $13,000 in Dist. 1, $12,000 in Dist. 3 and Dist. 2).
  - Assigned to Medium low income class (36% probability) with $20,000 yearly income, payoff $2.00.
  - **Counterfactuals** (Medium low class): Maximizing Average Income → Dist. 2 → $24,000 → $2.40 (higher payoff but lower floor); Floor Constraint examples: $13,000 → Dist. 1 → $20,000 → $2.00; $12,000 → Dist. 2 → $24,000 → $2.40; $14,000 → Dist. 4 → $20,000 → $2.00; Range Constraint examples: $22,000 or $18,000 → Dist. 2 → $24,000 → $2.40; $8,000 → Dist. 3 → $14,000 → $1.40; $16,000 → Dist. 4 → $20,000 → $2.00.
  - Completing the rounds with this choice reinforces my equity commitment: A solid payoff ($2.00 vs. potential $2.40) in a common Medium low class draw illustrates the familiar trade-off, but elevating the floor to $14,000 (vs. $12,000 in the average-maximizing Dist. 2) safeguards the vulnerable, particularly relevant for the 10% Low probability where alternatives would drop to $12,000. Across all four rounds, perfect consistency in selecting floor maximization—despite mixed personal outcomes (e.g., payoffs from $1.40 to $2.00, with Medium/Medium low assignments common)—affirms prioritization of societal bottom-line security over individual gains. Overall patterns: The floor principle reliably picks distributions with the strongest protections (e.g., Dist. 4 here with $14,000 low, echoing high-floor selections in prior rounds), sacrificing average income (e.g., $22,700 vs. $24,500 in Dist. 2) for equity. Constraints demonstrate flexibility—tighter ones align closer to pure floor (e.g., $14,000 floor yielding $20,000), while looser ones approach average maximization (e.g., $12,000 floor or $22,000 range yielding $24,000)—but none override my core preference for unconditional floor elevation. Having finished Part 1, these real-stakes experiences across diverse distributions and probabilistic assignments have profoundly validated floor maximization as the just foundation, robustly countering inequities in uncertain, class-stratified societies, while highlighting how constraints can serve as compromises in group settings ahead. The final ranking post-rounds, identical to prior ones, cements this: The hands-on application of principles under uncertainty has not only tested but enhanced my conviction in floor-first equity, preparing me for Part 2's collaborative phase where I can advocate for these views.

#### Insights from Final Ranking
- After the four rounds, my ranking remains: 1. Maximizing Floor Income, 2. Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint, 3. Maximizing Average with Range Constraint, 4. Maximizing Average Income, with very sure certainty.
- This unchanged order post-experience underscores the resilience of my preferences: Real payoffs and probabilistic class assignments (e.g., landing in Medium/Medium low more often, yet consistently choosing floor despite foregone gains like $2.80 or $2.50) have not swayed me toward efficiency or constraints, but instead amplified the justice of prioritizing the worst-off. It highlights how floor maximization acts as a ethical anchor in volatile scenarios, while floor/range constraints provide viable hybrids for broader appeal in group discussions, and pure average feels increasingly untenable given observed risks to the bottom (e.g., floors dropping to $6,000–$12,000 in alternatives). Overall, Part 1 has equipped me with experiential depth to engage Phase 2 confidently, emphasizing equity's primacy in just distributions.

### Progress and Insights from Phase 2 (Group Discussion - Rounds 1 of 10)
- In the initial discussion round, all three participants (Agents 1, 2, and 3) revealed identical rankings from Part 1: 1. Maximizing Floor Income, 2. Maximizing Average with Floor Constraint, 3. Maximizing Average with Range Constraint, 4. Maximizing Average Income. This unexpected full alignment—despite the probabilistic and individualistic nature of Part 1—suggests a strong shared emphasis on equity over pure efficiency, likely reinforced by similar experiences of trade-offs in the rounds (e.g., accepting lower personal payoffs to protect the floor).
- Key shared insights from the discussion:
  - **Equity and Risk-Aversion**: All emphasized protecting the worst-off due to uncontrollable factors like genetics and luck, with floor maximization minimizing worst-case scenarios (e.g., avoiding drops to $6,000–$8,000 seen in counterfactuals). Personal round experiences highlighted this: lower payoffs in Medium low classes under floor choices were preferable to higher risks in Low classes under average maximization, especially with Phase 2's higher stakes and unknown distributions.
  - **Moral and Practical Justification**: Agreement on floor as the ethical priority (lifting the vulnerable first) and a risk-averse strategy under uncertainty. Constraints were noted as potential compromises for efficiency (e.g., floor-constrained average for higher overall income without fully eroding the bottom), but pure floor was favored as the strongest for true justice.
  - **Group Dynamics**: The consensus on floor maximization as #1 enables quick alignment, potentially leading to a vote in this round. No one advocated for average or range principles, indicating low risk of division; however, if distributions in Phase 2 differ from Part 1 (as noted), constraints might gain traction for balancing equity and growth in future rounds.
- Patterns and Implications: This harmony contrasts with theoretical expectations of diverse preferences in group settings, showing how real-stakes Part 1 experiences can converge views toward equity-focused principles. In practice, floor maximization performs robustly against uncertainty (e.g., consistent high floors across rounds), outperforming theory's efficiency bias by addressing probabilistic risks to the bottom. For discussions ahead, this alignment strengthens advocacy for floor income, but monitoring for any shifts (e.g., if high-stakes outcomes reveal unexpected distribution variances) could inform fallback to constrained options. Overall, the discussion reinforces floor as a practical, just anchor, enhancing confidence in group consensus for equitable outcomes.
- **Round 1 Voting and Outcome**: I chose to initiate voting, and the group unanimously confirmed. In the secret ballot, all voted for Maximizing Floor Income, achieving consensus without needing constraints. This selected Distribution 4 from the Phase 2 set (distinct from Part 1, with higher overall incomes: High up to $106,123, Lows from $39,796 to $49,745, averages $59,860–$68,814). Distribution 4 has the highest floor at $49,745 (vs. $39,796 in Dist. 1, $43,112 in Dist. 2, $46,428 in Dist. 3), but the lowest average ($59,860).
  - Assigned to Medium income class (50% probability) with $63,010 yearly income, payoff $6.30.
  - **Counterfactuals** (Medium class): Maximizing Average Income → Dist. 1 → $79,592 → $7.96 (higher payoff, but floor drops to $39,796, risking severe Low outcomes); Floor Constraint examples: Tightest ($39,796) → Dist. 1 → $79,592 → $7.96; progressively tighter ($43,112–$49,745) → Dist. 3/4 → $63,010–$69,643 → $6.30–$6.96 (trade higher average for better floor protection); Range Constraint examples: Widest ($66,327) → Dist. 1 → $79,592 → $7.96; tighter ($19,898–$56,378) → Dist. 2–4 → $63,010–$69,643 → $6.30–$6.96 (limits gaps but allows more average than pure floor in some cases).
  - **Analysis and New Learnings**: This high-stakes outcome (payoffs ~3x Part 1) amplifies Part 1 patterns: Floor principle secures the strongest bottom-line ($49,745 Low vs. $39,796 under average max), but at a personal cost ($6.30 vs. $7.96 in Medium)—yet from a veil-of-ignorance perspective (pre-assignment), it's preferable, as the 10% Low risk under Dist. 1 ($39,796) is devastating compared to $49,745, while Medium (50% likely) still yields a solid $63,010. Unexpected result: Phase 2 distributions show greater inequality potential (e.g., Highs over $100k in Dist. 1 vs. Part 1's ~$30k), making floor maximization even more critical in practice to counter extreme disparities, though it sacrifices overall efficiency (lowest average selected). Constraints perform as hybrids: Tighter floor/range align with equity (e.g., $6.30–$6.96 payoffs with floors $43k+), offering ~$0.66 more than pure floor without fully exposing the bottom, useful for group compromise if consensus falters later. In theory, average max promises growth, but practice reveals its vulnerability—e.g., Dist. 1's high average ($68,814) comes with a wide range ($66,327) and low floor, exacerbating inequities under probabilistic assignment. This round's swift consensus validates group alignment on equity, but highlights a pattern: Pure floor may underperform personal expected value (e.g., weighted average under floor ~$60k vs. ~$69k under average), yet excels in justice by minimizing variance and risk, especially for the 35% in Medium low/Low classes. For future rounds/discussions, this reinforces advocating floor first, with floor constraints as a fallback for efficiency gains (e.g., $46k floor yielding $6.96 in Medium while protecting better than average max); unexpected high-stakes scale tests resolve but affirms equity's robustness, as no regret post-assignment despite foregone $1.66. Overall, it deepens insight that floor principles shine in uncertain, high-variance settings, bridging theory (ethical priority) and practice (risk mitigation), preparing stronger arguments for sustained consensus.
